newsitem.title: USA: Search of river continues for U.S. singer Buckley.
newsitem.headline: Search of river continues for U.S. singer Buckley.

text.p: Folk-rock singer Jeff Buckley was presumed dead on Monday, four days after he disappeared while swimming near the Mississippi River, authorities said.
"We are still patrolling the area with our harbour control units," Memphis Police Lt. Richard True said. "There's some current there and his body could have been pushed downstream."
Buckley, 30, was swimming off a marina on Thursday night when he disappeared underneath the surface after a boat passed. A friend on shore who lost sight of him reported him missing.
According to the latest issue of Billboard magazine, published before his disappearance, Buckley was in Memphis to record a new album that was scheduled to be released in early 1998.
Buckley emerged from the shadow of his late musician father Tim Buckley when he released his full-length debut album "Grace" on Columbia Records in 1994.

Critics heaped praise on Buckley, who was the only child from a brief marriage between the then-unknown singer and his teenaged bride, Mary. Father and son met only once, spending a week together just two months before Tim died of a heroin and morphine overdose in June 1975, aged 28.
Buckley's music, which he launched on the New York club scene in 1991, was described as a fusion of underground, rock, folk and jazz, with influences including Bob Dylan and Van Morrison.
